speaker: Neil
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

speaker: Sam
text: And I’m Sam.

speaker: Neil
text: Sam, would you describe yourself as ‘sporty’?

speaker: Sam
text: Well, I do like to go running and I might watch some sport on TV.

speaker: Neil
text: Would you watch sport like bandy, skeleton or perhaps luge?

speaker: Sam
text: Ah, you’re talking about quite specialised sports, played on ice or snow, and that’s because it’s almost time for the Winter Olympics.

speaker: Neil
text: Yes, you’re right. The 2022 Winter Olympics starts in Beijing on the 4th February. This event will mark the return of the Olympics to Beijing for the first time in 14 years, having previously hosted the 2008 Summer Games.

speaker: controversy
text: That means Beijing will become the first city in the world to have hosted both the Winter and Summer Games. But these latest Games are not without controversy – that’s disagreement or argument about something people have strong feelings about.

speaker: Neil
text: More about that later – but as usual, I have a question or you, Sam. The Winter Olympics have not been around as long as the Summer Olympics, so do you know when the first Winter event took place? Was it in:

speaker: Sam
text: Well, as they are relatively new, I’ll go for c) 1934.

speaker: discipline
text: OK, Sam, we’ll find out if that’s right later in the programme. Now, this latest Winter Olympics are scheduled to include a record 109 events over 15 disciplines in seven sports - biathlon, bobsledding, curling, ice hockey, luge, skating and skiing. A discipline in this context is a particular way of doing a sport.

speaker: Sam
text: The BBC’s China correspondent, Stephen McDonell, went to a recent test event for the Olympics and explained what the organisers are hoping for…

speaker: in full swingheadachesmemorable
text: In the mountains outside Beijing, the test events are in full swing. (The) Games organisers will be hoping (that) despite the coronavirus headaches, despite the alleged human rights abuses, despite the allegations from a former Chinese Olympian - a tennis star at that - involving a senior government official - they can still produce a memorable Winter Olympics.

speaker: in full swing
text: So that was Stephen McDonell at a test event which he described as being in full swing – so, at its highest level or activity – its busiest. And he mentioned the controversy surrounding the games.

speaker: headache
text: Yes, he mentioned the coronavirus headache – not an actual headache but something that causes a lot of problems. Covid-19 certainly makes it difficult to plan a huge event like this, particularly managing people who are travelling from all parts of the world.

speaker: Neil
text: On top of this, China is accused of human rights abuses against the Uighur Muslims. And there is the controversy around the tennis player, Peng Shuai.

speaker: memorable
text: But despite the issues facing the game’s organisers, they want to put on an event that is hard to forget, for good reasons – Stephen used the word memorable.

speaker: Neil
text: Well, seeing athletes hurtle down an icy track at 130 kilometres an hour on what looks like a tea tray, is certainly unforgettable. This is what they call ‘the skeleton’.

speaker: Sam
text: Let’s hear more about the preparations for the games from the BBC’s Stephen McDonell.

speaker: mountaindynamictheclock is ticking
text: The games will be held in a freezing, mostly dry area - a mountain of snow making is required, but this can make for quick, dynamic runs. The athletes we spoke to said these sites will make for high-quality competition - for everyone here, the clock is now ticking.

speaker: mountain
text: So, despite this being a winter event, held in a cold place, enormous quantities of artificial snow have to be made. Stephen McDonell describes this as a mountain of snow – not a real mountain – but a large amount of it.

speaker: dynamic
text: But some athletes say this type of snow is good for speed, and changing and developing – or dynamic – conditions. They hope it will be a ‘high-quality’ competition.

speaker: the clock is ticking
text: Let’s hope so, and it’s not long until it starts – and for the athletes the clock is ticking, meaning time is running out to prepare.

speaker: Sam
text: And our time is running out too, so Neil, what’s the answer to the question you asked me?

speaker: Neil
text: Oh yes, I asked you when the first Winter Olympics took place?

speaker: Sam
text: And I said 1934.

speaker: Neil
text: Which was… I’m afraid to say, Sam, the wrong answer. The first Winter Olympic Games took place in 1924 and were held in Chamonix in the French Alps. The Beijing Winter Olympics is the 24th games. And the Paralympic Games will take place a month later in the city, between 4th and 13th March 2022.

speaker: controversy
text: Looks like I need to brush up on my Winter Olympics knowledge but not before we recap some of the vocabulary we’ve mentioned, starting with controversy – disagreement or argument about something people have strong feelings about.

speaker: in full swing
text: We talked about something being in full swing – so, at its highest level of activity.

speaker: headache
text: And a headache is, metaphorically, something that causes you a lot of problems.

speaker: mountain
text: A mountain is not only a very high hill - used metaphorically it means a large amount of something.

speaker: dynamic
text: Something continually changing and developing can be described as dynamic.

speaker: the clock is ticking
text: And finally, the clock is ticking, means time is running out to prepare for or complete something.

speaker: Sam
text: Well, the clock is no longer ticking for us because our six minutes are up!

speaker: Neil
text: Goodbye for now!

speaker: Sam
text: Bye bye!
